_prev_prog_2.Description:
VWR has compiled information that is necessary for safe handling and storage of regulated chemical products.  This information includes:

* Material safety data sheets (MSDSs) for each regulated chemical.  This information is available electronically or as a hard copy.  The last MSDS revision was July 2000;

* Maximum intended inventory of equipment in which regulated chemicals are stored.  (i.e., the maximum intended container size is 55 gallons for both hydrochloric acid and chloroform).  The estimated maximum inventory of hydrochloric acid is 14,000 lbs; the maximum inventory of chloroform is estimated at 30,000 lbs. 

* Acceptable storage temperatures and conditions. (Special conditions --   Acids to be stored separately from ammonium hydroxide.);

* Equipment use and maintenance specifications (Use and maintenance specifications for forklifts, storage rack, and other equipment are maintained on file at the facility.)  Appendix C of VWR's IPRP displays the preventative maintenance procedures for equipment involved in the receipt, warehousing, transport and storage of regulated chemical materials;

* Codes and standards used to design and build the facility:
  NFPA 30 (Flammable & Combustible Liquids), NFPA 231 (Standard for General Storage), NFPA 231c (Standard for Rack Storage of Materials).


Hazard Review

The hazards associated with the regulated chemicals are:

* Corrosivity
* Toxicity

VWR periodically reviews and audits its operations to identify and control potential hazards.  The original hazard review/audit was completed June 21, 1999.  On September 10, 2001, the hazard review was updated as a result of NJ DEP recommendations and the predictive filing of chloroform.  The review updated upon the 1993 What-If Analysis conducted in a prior TCPA submission, and also utilized the Chemical Manufacturer Association's Warehouse Assessment Protocol.  This Warehouse Assessment Protocol document is cited, in EPA's guidance document Risk Management Program for Warehouses (40 CFR Part 68, as providing a suitable framework for conducting a hazard review.  Additionally, facility personnel and other persons familiar with warehouse operations provided input to the hazard review process.

Major hazards identified during this review were:

* Toxic release
* Equipment failure


Current facility management practices were deemed appropriate to prevent a toxic release, fire or explosion.  For example, the existence of standard operating procedures and training programs help minimize the risk of human error associated with facility operations.  Similarly, daily inspection of forklifts and the use of a standard checklist, help ensure that forklifts do not fail while in use.  

If a chemical release were to occur, it would first be detected by an operator, either visually or by odor.  Once detected, the facility has direct-reading colorimetric detection equipment that can determine the concentration of the chemical in air (measured in parts per million, or percent).

Mitigation systems and equipment are available for use by trained VWR emergency response personnel, in the event of a release.  A corrosives spill can be controlled through a special neutralizing and absorbing material, which is applied to the spill.  Similarly, toxic substances can be absorbed and containerized for later disposal.  Mitigation systems for a fire or explosion include a system of sprinklers, dikes, fire walls, and blast panels.

Although findings from the hazard review were favorable, action items were identified, as follows:

* Label storage rack with maximum weight capacity to prevent overload and damage to the rack.
* Develop in-house procedures for employee action in the event of discovery of a rack failure.

The anticipated completion date of the action items is October 11, 2001.


Year 2000 (Y2K) Safety Issues

In late 1999, VWR considered the potential impact of a Y2K-related microchip failure on company operations.  The following table lists systems that are important to safety preparedness and response, and possible consequences of a system failure.

*Building System > Consequence of Failure

*Fire Alarm > Alarm may not work
*Natural Gas > Loss of heat, and freezing/rupture of fire sprinklers
*Water > No water available for fire sprinkler system
*Electricity > Loss of power (however, alarm and lighting systems have battery backup)
*Phone > Unable to call for emergency assistance

The loss of natural gas for an extended period of time could cause freezing and rupture of sprinkler pipes, and could possibly precipitate an emergency event.  Likewise, a loss of electricity could precipitate a freezing event if the heating system (i.e., fans) do not operate.  A failure in any of the other systems is unlikely to precipitate an emergency event, but could affect the effectiveness of response, if for any reason, an emergency were to occur.

All of the listed systems and equipment are furnished and/or serviced by outside vendors.  Therefore, VWR has undertaken a process to ensure that vendor systems are Y2K compliant.  This process involved calling or writing to vendors and requesting written confirmation of their compliance status.

The Y2K review process covered many broad areas of facility emergency planning directly and indirectly affecting the receiving, warehousing, putaway and picking of hazardous substances.  That review proved to be valuable in predicting potential major business disruptions and upset conditions, as no significant Y2K-related incidents occurred in the year 2000 or thereafter.


Operating Procedures

VWR maintains written procedures for most operations.  Appendix C of VWR's Risk Management Plan identifies procedures relating to normal start-up and routine operations; Section 2 for procedures relating to emergency shut-down, evacuation and emergency operations, and start-up following an emergency shut-down.   Section 2 includes procedures for temporary operations during an emergency. The issuance or revision date is shown on procedures to indicated the date of last review.


Training

VWR provides employee training for routine operations and emergency situations.  The training process can include one or more instructional formats, such as: lecture; videotape; interactive computer-based training hands-on exercises, demonstrations and on the job training.  Training is conducted by a qualified instructor or other competent person.  Employee proficiency may be evaluated using one or more techniques, including classroom quiz, actual demonstration, or verbal assessment.

VWR has reviewed the capabilities of existing employees as of June 21, 1999.  This review determined that the employees possess the knowledge, skill and ability to perform their duties in accordance with operating procedures.  A written certification documenting the original determination was prepared and is on file at VWR. 

New employees and employees who are transferred to new responsibilities receive training prior to starting the job.  This ensures that all employees understand and can perform their duties in accordance with operating procedures.

Employees will be re-trained whenever operating procedures are significantly revised, and at least once every three years, even if procedures have not changed.  

For administrative efficiency, training under this section may be combined with any other employee training provided by VWR.

VWR has formally asked each of its on-site contractors to certify in writing that their people working on-site have been trained in accordance with the proper safety and environmental health standards, and they currently adhere to all applicable regulations for the same.


Maintenance

VWR maintains a list of process equipment that requires routine inspection and maintenance.  There are written procedures relating to inspection and maintenance requirements.  Personnel responsible for inspection and maintenance are trained on these procedures.  The procedures are typically developed by VWR or are obtained from equipment manufacturers.  A list of Standard Operating Procedures and Preventative Maintenance Procedures relevant to VWR's IPRP have been included in Appendix C.


Compliance Audits

VWR will conduct an audit at least once every three (3) years to evaluate compliance with Prevention Program requirements.  The first audit will be completed no later than June 21, 2003.  Findings and recommended corrective actions will be put in writing, and corrective actions will be implemented in a timely manner.  Upon completion of corrective actions VWR will provide a written certification that the compliance evaluations has been completed.  All written records relating to compliance audits will be retained for at least (5) five years.


Incident Investigation

VWR's emergency procedures include a provision for conducting an investigation and analysis of each incident in which the emergency plan is activated .  Because VWR investigates all incidents, this procedure satisfies the requirement that VWR investigate each incident that "resulted in, or could have resulted in a catastrophic release of a regulated substance."  

Each incident report, and corrective actions, will be put in writing.  Corrective actions will be implemented promptly.  The results of the investigation will be reviewed with affected workers (VWR and vendors) whose job tasks are relevant to the incident.  The incident report will be retained for minimum of five (5) years.  At a minimum, a summary shall be prepared including the following elements:
* a description of the event;
* date of the accident or potential accident;
* date the investigation was begun;
* factors contributing to the accident or event;
* any recommendations resulting from the investigation.

Corrective actions will be implemented promptly.  The results of the investigation will be reviewed with affected workers (VWR and vendors) whose job tasks are relevant to the incident.  The incident investigation report and all supporting documentation will be retained for a minimum of five (5) years.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
VWR International, Inc. (VWR) is a distributor of high-quality chemicals and laboratory supplies.  The chemical products sold by VWR are received from manufacturers in Department of Transportation (DOT)-approved containers (typically ranging from 1 gallon to 55 gallons in volume).  VWR does not manufacture, formulate or otherwise engage in direct handling of chemicals outside of the containers in which the chemicals are received.  VWR operations consist of warehousing and distribution activities, and the risk of a serious chemical-related emergency is low.  However, VWR has a strong commitment to the safety and well-being of its employees, the environment and the surrounding community.  The company has established a management system, consisting of policies, procedures, training, inspection, maintenance and other elements, that are designed to prevent incidents from occurring, and in the event a minor or major emergency does occur, to enable facility personnel to effectively manage the incident. 

All warehousing operations involving regulated chemicals are considered a single "covered process" for regulatory purposes.  The VWR facility is considered to be covered under the Program 2 eligibility requirements (per 68.10(c)) because New Jersey does not recognize Program 1 and VWR is not covered by one of the SIC codes listed under Program 3 nor OSHA's Process Safety Management requirements.  

At the present time, only Hydrochloric Acid solution (>36%) exceeds the Threshold Quantity (TQ) for that substance under the revised New Jersey Toxic Catastrophe Prevention Act (NJ TCPA) with an estimated maximum quantity of 14,000 lbs as compared to the NJ TCPA TQ of 5,600 lbs.  VWR is also predictively filing for chloroform, even though at most times the quantity of chloroform is less than the TQ of 20,000 lbs.

Worst Case and Alternative Release Off-Site Consequence scenarios were analyzed for both hydrochloric acid and chloroform using the same considerations.  This is becau

se both are handled and stored in the same sizes and types of containers under identical receiving and storage process conditions described in VWR SOP WH-092.

The worst case release scenario is based on a hypothetical incident in which the single largest container stored on site, a 55 gallon drum, is pierced by a forklift and the contents are spilled on the floor of the distribution center.  RMP Comp, a software program furnished by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), was used to determine the farthest distance from the facility that toxic effects may be anticipated, following the chemical release.  This is known as the distance to the "toxic" endpoint.  

Results of the worst case analysis indicate that all distances to endpoints are relatively small.  The estimated distance to the toxic endpoint for hydrochloric acid was determined to be approxiimately 0.7 miles.  The worst case distance for chloroform was 0.1 miles or less.  There are no residences, schools or hospitals within that distance, although a few commercial industrial establishments exist within that radius. 

The alternative release scenario is based on a more realistic hypothetical incident in which a single 4-liter (approximately 1 gallon) container of chemical is dropped on the floor.   According to the analysis, the distance to the toxic endpoint was equal to one-tenth of one mile (0.1 mile) or less for both hydrochloric acid and chloroform. 

Administrative controls and active mitigation measures were not included as a factor of consideration during the worst case or alternative release scenarios.   However, release inside the building, as well as passive mitigation measures (i.e., enclosures and berms) were included. 

VWR's prevention program consists of several key elements, including:

* Safety Information - includes detailed information about the hazards of regulated chemicals, maximum intended inventory, facility design features, applicable standards, equipment use and maintenan

ce.

* Hazard Review - a process of evaluating facility operations, using "what-if" analysis and warehouse industry checklists were conducted to identify and control potential hazards.

* Operating Procedures - written procedures to guide employees in safely conducting normal, temporary and emergency operations.

* Training - includes training commensurate with the types of activities employees are expected to perform during normal and emergency situations.

* Maintenance - required maintenance activities are performed by trained employees or qualified vendors.

* Compliance Audits - conducted at least once every three years to verify compliance with regulatory requirements for Accidental Release Prevention.

* Incident Investigation - conducted whenever an incident occurs that results in, or could have resulted in, a catastrophic release (i.e., a release that presents an imminent and substantial endangerment to public health and the environment).

The need for chemical specific prevention steps is very limited because chemicals are contained within sealed, DOT-approved containers, and the containers are not opened during handling.   Additionally, all chemicals are segregated and stored by hazard class, to ensure that incompatible chemicals are not stored together.

There have been no accidents in the previous five years that have resulted in any deaths or significant property damage
